entry.title: [CF1202E You Are Given Some Strings...] Solution
entry.content:
[CF1202E You AreGiven Some Strings...] Solution

Problem Link: CF1202E You AreGiven Some Strings...

Meaning:

Given a text string \(t\) and \(n\) pattern strings \(s_i\), find \[\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^nf(s_i + s_j)\] \(f(s)\) is defined as thenumber of occurrences of \(s\) in \(t\), and \(s_i +s_j\) is defined as the splice strings \(s_i\) and \(s_j\).

Input:

One line \(t\), one line \(n\), and the next \(n\) line \(s_i\).

Output:

Answer.

Data Range:

\(1\le |t|,\sum |s_i| \le 2\times10^5\) .

This kind of question must consider the contribution of a certainstring.

Here we consider the enumeration division point \(x\). Denote the point before as \(s_i\) and the point after as \(s_j\)

Count the number of \(f(x),g(x+1)\)before and after each \(x\).

How do we count them? Notice that \(f(x)\) is actually how many knownsubstrings are in the suffix of \(t_{1 \cdotsx}\) and \(g(x)\) is the reverseof \(f(x)\) .

This is something that can be messed with using AC automata. That is,build the AC automaton directly on the pattern string and run \(t\) through it.

Consider that the fail pointer points to the longest suffix from theroot to the current string, and then the request is equivalent to thenumber of suffixes for the pattern string.

As we know from the AC automaton's code, this is simply a matter ofsumming over the fail tree.

Time Complexity is \(\mathcal{O}(\sum |s_i|\times |\Sigma|)\)

Code:

#include <bits/stdc++.h>using namespace std;#define int long long#define INF 0x3f3f3f3f3f3f3f3fvoid up(int &x,int y) { x < y ? x = y : 0; }void down(int &x,int y) { x > y ? x = y : 0; }#define N ((int)(4e5+15))struct Trie{    queue<int> q;    int tot,trie[N][26],ed[N],fail[N];    void insert(char *s)    {        int u = 0;        for(int i=1; s[i]; i++)        {            int c = s[i] - 'a';            if(!trie[u][c]) trie[u][c] = ++tot;            u = trie[u][c];        }        ++ed[u];    }    void build()    {        for(int i=0; i<26; i++) if(trie[0][i]) q.push(trie[0][i]);        for(int u; !q.empty(); )        {            u = q.front(); q.pop();            for(int i=0; i<26; i++)            {                if(trie[u][i])                {                    fail[trie[u][i]] = trie[fail[u]][i];                    ed[trie[u][i]] += ed[fail[trie[u][i]]]; q.push(trie[u][i]);                }else trie[u][i] = trie[fail[u]][i];            }        }    }    void query(char *s,int *f)    {        int u = 0;        for(int i=1; s[i]; i++)        { u = trie[u][s[i] - 'a']; f[i] = ed[u]; }    }}tr1,tr2;char s[N],t[N]; int f[N],g[N];signed main(){    ios::sync_with_stdio(0);    cin.tie(0);cout.tie(0);    // freopen("check.in","r",stdin);    // freopen("check.out","w",stdout);    int n,l; cin >> (t + 1) >> n; l = strlen(t + 1);    for(int i=1; i<=n; i++)    {        cin >> (s + 1); tr1.insert(s);        reverse(s + 1, s + 1 + strlen(s + 1)); tr2.insert(s);    }    tr1.build(); tr2.build(); tr1.query(t,f);    reverse(t + 1, t + 1 + l); tr2.query(t,g);    // for(int i=1; i<=l; i++) cout << f1[i] << " \n"[i==l];    // for(int i=1; i<=l; i++) cout << f2[i] << " \n"[i==l];    int res = 0;    for(int i=1; i<=l; i++) res += f[i] * g[l - i];    cout << res << '\n';    return 0;}

References：

[1] https://www.luogu.com.cn/blog/c2522943959/solution-cf1202e

entry.title: [Luogu P2656 采蘑菇] Solution
entry.content:
[Luogu P2656 采蘑菇] Solution

Problem Link: P2656采蘑菇

Meaning:

q779 and cxy are going to a forest to pick mushrooms.

There are \(N\) bushes in the forestand \(M\) trails, each of which is aone-way path connecting two bushes with a certain number of mushrooms.q779 and cxy can pick all the mushrooms on a path by passing it once.Since the forest is a magically fertile land, after the mushrooms on apath are picked, new mushrooms will grow, multiplying the number ofmushrooms by the "recovery factor" of the path \(c\) and rounding down.

For example, if there are \(4\)mushrooms on a path and the "recovery factor" of the path is \(c = 0.7\), then the number of mushroomsthat can be picked from the first to the fourth time through the path is\(4,2,1,0\) respectively.

Now, q779 and cxy start from bush \(S\) and find the maximum number ofmushrooms they can pick.

Input:

Two integers, \(N\) and \(M\), in the first row.

The second to \(M+1\) rows, fournumbers per row, denote the starting point, the ending point, theinitial number of mushrooms and the recovery factor of a trail,respectively.

In the \(M+2\) th row, an integer\(S\).

Output:

One integer in a row indicates the maximum number of mushrooms thatcan be picked, ensuring that the answer does not exceed \(2^{31}-1\).

Data range:

\(1 \le N\le 8\times 10^4,~1\le M\le2\times 10^5,~0\le c\le 0.8\) and up to one decimal, \(1\le S\le N\).

The first problem solution after the resurrection, also awarm-up question.

Anyway, may my dream come true in NOIP.

Notice that an edge can be walked an infinite number of times,

then any strongly connected component can be walked until it does notgrow mushrooms.

Consider shrinking points and preprocessing the answer for eachstrongly connected component

Then it becomes simple "do topo+dp on DAG"

The time complexity is \(\mathcal{O}(m\log_{\frac{4}{5}} M)\), in short, can be passed.

code:

#include <bits/stdc++.h>using namespace std;#define int long long#define INF 0x3f3f3f3f3f3f3f3fvoid up(int &x,int y) { x < y ? x = y : 0; }void down(int &x,int y) { x > y ? x = y : 0; }#define N ((int)(8e4 + 15))#define M ((int)(2e5 + 15))int n,m,s,pos=1,scnt,stktop,head[N],f[N],g[N];int dfn[N],low[N],stk[N],scc[N],val[N]; bitset<N> ins;struct Edge { int u,v,w,c,next; } e[M];void addEdge(int u,int v,int w,double c){ e[++pos] = {u,v,w,(int)(c * 10),head[u]}; head[u] = pos; }void Tarjan(int u){    static int tim = 0;    dfn[u] = low[u] = ++tim; ins[u] = 1; stk[++stktop] = u;    for(int i=head[u]; i; i=e[i].next)    {        int v = e[i].v; if(!dfn[v])        {            Tarjan(v); down(low[u], low[v]);        }else if(ins[v]) down(low[u], dfn[v]);    }    if(dfn[u] == low[u])    {        ++scnt;        for(int p = 0; p != u; )        { p = stk[stktop--]; ins[p] = 0; scc[p] = scnt; }    }}signed main(){    ios::sync_with_stdio(0);    cin.tie(0);cout.tie(0);    // freopen("check.in","r",stdin);    // freopen("check.out","w",stdout);    cin >> n >> m;    for(int i=1,u,v,w; i<=m; i++)    {        static double c;        cin >> u >> v >> w >> c; addEdge(u,v,w,c);    }    cin >> s; Tarjan(s);    pos = 1; for(int i=1; i<=n; i++) head[i] = 0;    for(int i=2; i <= m+1; i++)    {        int u = scc[e[i].u], v = scc[e[i].v];        if(!(u && v)) continue;        if(u != v) addEdge(u,v,e[i].w,-1);        else while(e[i].w){ g[u] += e[i].w; e[i].w = e[i].w * e[i].c / 10; }      }    // for(int i=1; i<=scnt; i++) cout << f[i] << " \n"[i==scnt];    // for(int i=2; i<=pos; i++) cout << e[i].u << ' ' << e[i].v << ' ' << e[i].w << '\n';    for(int u = scnt; u; u--)    {        if(!f[u]) f[u] = g[u];        for(int i=head[u]; i; i=e[i].next)        { int v = e[i].v; up(f[v], f[u] + e[i].w + g[v]); }    }    cout << *max_element(f + 1, f + 1 + scnt) << '\n';    return 0;}

It is a bit difficult to translate the solution into English, but Iwill try.

There was a phrase here in the Chinese solution, but I'm notgoing to translate it.

entry.title: The equation of a circle
entry.content:
The equation of a circle

采用 DeepL翻译，目前的问题是中文的句子我是凑好宽度写的，但是英文没有。

可能会在将来的版本中解决这个问题。

Using DeepL to translate, the current problem is that the Chinesesentences I am putting together are written with good width, but theEnglish is not. I will probably fix this problem in a futureversion.

I. Standard equation of acircle

In a plane right angle coordinate system, if the coordinates of thecenter and radius of a circle are determined, the circle is uniquelydetermined.

Then the standard equation of a circle with \((a,b)\) as the center and \(r\) as the radius is \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2 ~(r >0)\)

In particular, the unit circle is \(x^2 +y^2 = r^2\).

II. General equation of acircle

The equation \(x^2+y^2+D x+Ey+F=0\left(D^2+E^2-4 F>0\right)\) is called the generalequation of a circle.

Converted to the standard equation as \[\left(x+\frac{D}{2}\right)^2+\left(y+\frac{E}{2}\right)^2=\frac{D^2+E^2-4F}{4}\]

  • When \(D^2+E^2-4 F>0\), \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F=0\) represents acircle.

    At this point the center of the circle is \(\left(-\frac{D}{2},-\frac{E}{2}\right)\)and the radius of the circle is \(\frac{\sqrt{D^2+E^2-4 F}}{2}\).

  • When \(D^2+E^2-4 F=0\), \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F=0\) denotes a point \(\left(-\frac{D}{2},-\frac{E}{2}\right)\).

  • When \(D^2+E^2-4 F<0\), \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F=0\) does not representany graph.

From the form of the equation, we know that the general equation of acircle contains three letters

Therefore, under general conditions, the general equation of thecircle can be solved by always three independent conditions.

The following cases are more applicable to the general equation of acircle.

  1. Find the coefficients \(D,E,F\)by substituting the coordinates of three points on a circle into thegeneral equation of the circle.

  2. The two points on the circle and the line where the center of thecircle is located are known

    Consider substituting two points into the equation of a circle bysubstituting the center of the circle \(\left(-\frac{D}{2},-\frac{E}{2}\right)\)into the equation of the line in which the center of the circle lies andfinding the coefficients \(D,E,F\) tobe determined.

Expand.

The relationship between the quadratic equation and the equation of acircle.

The binary quadratic equation \(A x^2+B xy+C y^2+D x+E y+F=0\) forms a circle under the condition that\[\begin{cases}A=C \neq 0\\\[6pt]B=0\\\[6pt]\left(\dfrac{D}{A}\right)^2+\left(\dfrac{E}{A}\right)^2-4\left(\dfrac{F}{A}\right)>0\end{cases}\]

III.Position relationship between points and circles

Judgment method.

  1. Geometric method: i.e., determine the relationship between \(r\) and \(|OA|\) in terms of magnitude.

  2. Algebraic method: Judging from the relationship between thecoordinates of a point and the equation of a circle

    Standard equation: The point \(P(x_0,y_0)\) is known and the equation ofthe circle \((x-a)^2+(y-b)^2=r^2\)

    • The point \(P\) is outside thecircle, then \((x-a)^2+(y-b)^2 >r^2\).
    • The point \(P\) is on the circle,then \((x-a)^2+(y-b)^2 = r^2\).
    • The point \(P\) is inside thecircle, then \((x-a)^2+(y-b)^2 <r^2\)

    General equation: The point \(P(x_0,y_0)\) is known and the equation ofthe circle \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F=0\)

    • The point \(P\) is outside thecircle, then \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F >0\).
    • The point \(P\) is on the circle,then \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F = 0\).
    • The point \(P\) is inside thecircle, then \(x^2+y^2+D x+E y+F <0\)

IV. Symmetry problemsrelated to circles

Axial symmetry of a circle: the circle is symmetric about the linewhere the diameter is located.

The circle is symmetric about the point.

  1. To find a circle with known circle symmetry about a point, youonly need to determine the location of the center of the circle you arelooking for.

  2. If two circles are symmetric about a point, then this point isthe midpoint of the line connecting the centers of the twocircles.

  3. The circle is symmetric about the line

    1. To find a circle with known circle symmetry about a certain line,you only need to determine the position of the center of the circle youare looking for.

    2. If two circles are symmetric about a line, the line is theperpendicular bisector of the line joining the centers of the twocircles.

V. Equation oftrajectory and its solution

The equation of a trajectory refers to the equation of a curve formedby a moving point that moves according to certain rules.

There are three general methods to find the equation of thetrajectory of a curve: the direct method, the substitution method, andthe definition method.

1. direct method

The steps are as follows.

  1. Establish the right-angle coordinate system
  2. let \((x,y)\) denote the movingpoint \(P\)
  3. equate \(x,y\) with theequation
  4. Simplify the equation. For some cases, special points on the curvemay have to be discarded.

2. substitution method

Generally used to deal with an active point and a passive point

Simply find the relationship between the coordinates of these twopoints, and then substitute the equation of the trajectory satisfied bythe active point to obtain the equation satisfied by the passivepoint.

3. definition method

Firstly, the known conditions and the definition of the curve to getwhat kind of curve for the trajectory, and then from the standardequation of this kind of curve to find the equation of thetrajectory.

4. Example questions

Example.

If a point \(P\) moves on a circle\(C : x^2+y^2-8 x-6 y+21=0\) and \(O\) is the origin, find the equation of thetrajectory of the midpoint \(M\) of theline \(OP\).

Solution.

  1. Direct method (this question is solved in the same way asthe substitution method).

    Let the coordinates of \(M\) be\((x,y)\) and the coordinates of thepoint \(P\) be \((x_0,y_0)\), then \(x = \frac{x_0}{2}, y = \frac{y_0}{2}\),i.e. \(x_0 = 2x,y_0 = 2y\).

    Since the point \(P(x_0,y_0)\) is onthe circle \(C : x^2 + y ^ 2 - 8x - 6y + 21 =0\)

    So \(x_0^2 + y_0^2 - 8x_0 - 6y_0 + 21 =0\), so \((2 x)^2+(2 y)^2-8 \times(2x)-6 \times(2 y)+21 = 0\).

    That is, the equation of the trajectory of the point \(M\) is \(x^2 +y^2 - 4x - 3y + \frac{21}{4} = 0\).

  2. Definition Method.

    As shown on the right, let the coordinates of the point \(M\) be \((x,y)\) connected to \(OC,PC\) and take the terminal \(A\) of the line \(OC\) and connect \(MA\).

    The equation of the circle \(C\) canbe reduced to \((x - 4) ^ 2 + (y - 3)^2 =4\) with the center \(C\) at\((4,3)\) and \(|CP| = 2\), then the coordinates of thepoint \(A\) are \((2,\frac{3}{2})\).

    In \(\triangle OCP\), \(M,A\) are the midpoints of \(OP,OC\), respectively, then \(|M A|=\frac{1}{2}|C P|=1\)

    When \(O,C,P\) are co-linear, \(|MA| = 1\), the path of \(M\) is a circle with \(A\) as the center and \(1\) as the radius.

    Therefore, the equation of the trajectory of the point \(M\) is \((x -2)^2 + (y - \frac{3}{2})^2 = 1\).

VI.Maximum value of the distance from a point to a circle

Given a point \(P(x_0,y_0)\)(not necessarily a fixed point), find the maximum andminimum values of \(P\) to a point\(Q\) on the circle \(C:(x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\).

The answer is given here first. \[\begin{aligned}&d_{\max} = |PO|_{\max} + r\\[6pt]&d_{\min} = |PO|_{\min} - r\end{aligned}\] Certificate.

Consider the optimal \(Q\) when the\(P\) point is fixed, according to theconclusion \(Q_0,Q_0^{\prime}\) whichcorresponds to the location of the \(Q\) point when the maximum and minimumvalues are taken.

It is easy to find that \(|PQ_0| = |PO| +|OQ_1| > |PQ_1|\), so the \(Q\) point must be at \(Q_0\) when taking the maximum value. \(\square\)

It is emphasized here that when fixing \(P\), that is, \(P\) is not necessarily a fixed point, butfor each position of \(P\), thereexists a corresponding \(Q_0\), and theconclusion still holds.

VII. Expansion: ApolloniusCircle

1. definition reference

This is not in the scope of the entrance exam, but you can find outabout it, and the exam will be given in the form of materials.

It is recommended to understand only the examples (~~ really someonelike me idle to read the Chinese wiki ~~)

The Apollonios circles are two related families ofcircles. Each blue circle of the first circle family is orthogonal to each redcircle of the second circle family. These circles form the base ofthe bipolarcoordinate system.

The Apollonios circle is defined by a line segment, label this linesegment as \(CD\).

First Family (Blue Circle)

Each circle in the first family is determined by a positivereal number \(r\), and thesecircles are defined as the trajectories of points \(X\) that satisfy the following conditions\[\left\{X \mid \frac{d(X, C)}{d(X, D)}=r\right\}\] That is, the ratio of the distance from \(X\) to \(C\) to the distance from \(X\) to \(D\) is \(r\).

When \(r\) is very close to zero,the corresponding circle will be closer to the side of \(C\) and vice versa to the side of \(D\).

When \(r=1\), the circle degeneratesto the midline of the line \(CD\).

Family II (red circle)

Each circle in the second family is determined by the angle \(\vartheta\), and these circles are definedas the trajectories of points \(X\)that satisfy the following conditions \[\{X \mid \measuredangle C X D=\theta\}\] where \(\measuredangle CXD\)denotes the directed angle of CXD. When \(\vartheta\) takes all values between \(0\) and \(\pi\), the above equation generates allcircles passing through \(C\) and \(D\)

2. Example questions

Apollonius was a famous mathematician in ancient Greece, who wascalled the three giants of mathematics in the Alexandrian periodtogether with Euclid and Archimedes. He had a profound and systematicstudy of the circular pheasant curve, and his main research results wereconcentrated in his masterpiece "Theory of the Circular PheasantCurve".

The Apollonius circle is one of his research results and refersto.

We know that the ratio of the distance between the moving point \(M\) and the two fixed points \(A, B\) is \(\lambda(\lambda>0, \lambda \neq 1)\),then the trajectory of the point \(M\)is an Apollonius circle.

The Apollonius circle is \(x^2+y^2=9\) if the ratio of the distancebetween the moving point \(M\) and thetwo fixed points \(A\left(\frac{9}{5},0\right), B(5,0)\) is \(\frac{3}{5}\).

In the following, we examine a related issue.

Given a moving point \(M\) on thecircle \(O: x^2+y^2=1\) and fixedpoints \(A\left(-\frac{1}{2}, 0\right),B(1,1)\), then the minimum of \(2|MA|+|M B|\) is _________.

Solution.

As shown, take the point \(K(-2,0)\)and connect \(OM,MK\).

Since \(|OM| = 1,|OA| = \frac{1}{2},|OK| =2\), so \(\frac{|OM|}{|OA|} =\frac{|OK|}{|OM|} = 2\).

And since \(\measuredangle MOK=\measuredangle AOM\), so \(\triangleMOK \sim \triangle AOM\), then \(\frac{|M K|}{|M A|}=\frac{|O M|}{|OA|}=2\), so \(|MK| =2|MA|\).

So \(|M B|+2|M A|=|M B|+|M K|\), andin \(\triangle MBK\), \(|MB| + |MK|\ge |BK|\), such that \[|MB| + 2|MA| = \left(|MB + |MK|\right)_{\min} = |BK| =\sqrt{(-2-1)^2+(0-1)^2} = \sqrt{10}\] Therefore, the answer is \(\sqrt{10}\).

VIII.The position relationship between a line and a circle anddetermination

Judgment method.

  1. Algebraic method.

    A system of equations is formed by associating the equations of aline with those of a circle, and the system of equations is studiedaccording to the number of solutions** of the **system of equations.

    • If \(\Delta > 0\), the lineintersects the circle.
    • If \(\Delta = 0\) , then the lineis tangent to the circle.
    • If \(\Delta < 0\), the line isseparated from the circle.

  2. Geometric method.

    Just determine the relationship between \(d\) and \(r\), as shown above (\(d\) can be calculated using thepoint-to-linear distance formula)

IX.The tangent line problem of a circle and the method of solving theequation of the tangent line

Analysis of key ideas.

  1. When a line is tangent to a circle, the conclusion \(d=r\) must be used
  2. When a line \(l\) is tangent to acircle \(C\), \(l \ perp PC\).
  3. A tangent line from a point \(P\)outside the circle to the circle \(C\)with tangent point \(Q\) must be usedto \(|PC|^2 = |PQ|^2 + r^2\).

A friendly reminder: there are many \((x_0,y_0)\) in the following, please do notconfuse their meaning.

1. the number of tangent lines

The tangent line of a circle drawn through a point in the plane.

  • If the point is outside the circle, then two tangents to the circlecan be made through this point.
  • If the point is on a circle, only one tangent line to the circle canbe made through this point, and this point is a tangent line.
  • If a point is inside a circle, a tangent to the circle cannot bemade through this point.
2.the equation of the tangent to the circle through a point outside thecircle

The two tangents to the circle are drawn through apoint outside the circle \(P(x_0,y_0)\).

  1. ** First assume that the slope of the tangent line exists ** andis \(k\) and that there are two ways tofind \(k\) as follows.

    1. Geometric method.

      Let the tangent equation \(y - y_0 = k(x -x_0)\) , be reduced to the general equation \(kx - y + y_0 - kx_0 = 0\).

      Since the line is tangent to the circle, the distance from the centerof the circle to the line is equal to the radius, which leads to \(k\).

    2. Algebraic method.

      Let the equation of the tangent line be \(y- y_0 = k (x - x_0)\), in conjunction with the equation of thecircle \((x - a) ^ 2 + (y - b) ^ 2 =r^2\)

      The equation is reduced to a quadratic equation with respect to \(x\), and then the discriminant is \(0\) to find \(k\).

  2. If only one slope \(k\)is found by the above method, then the slope of the othertangent line must not exist, and the equation of the other tangent lineis then \(x = x_0\).

3.the equation of the tangent line with slope \(k\) and tangent to a circle

  1. Geometric method.

    First, let the tangent equation be \(y = kx+ m\) and reduce it to the general equation \(kx - y + m = 0\).

    Then use the distance from the center of the circle to the tangentline to equal the radius to find the equation \(m\).

  2. Algebraic method.

    Let the equation of the tangent line be \(y= kx + m\), and the equation of the circle \((x - a) ^ 2 + (y - b) ^ 2 = r^2\).

    The equation is reduced to a quadratic equation with respect to \(x\), and then the discriminant is \(0\) to find \(m\).

4.the equation of the tangent line of a circle passing through a point onthe circle

Set a point on the circle \(Q(x_0,y_0)\) .

  1. Seeking method.

    First, find the slope of the line connecting the tangent point to thecenter of the circle \(k(k \ne 0)\),then the slope of the tangent line is \(-\frac{1}{k}\) by the verticalrelationship

    The tangent equation can be obtained from the point-slope equation.If \(k = 0\) or the slope does notexist, the tangent equation is obtained directly from thegraph.

  2. Major findings.

    1. The equation of the tangent line across the unit circle \(x^2 + y^2 = r^2\) is \[x_0x + y_0y = r^2\]

    2. over the circle \((x - a)^2 + (y - b) ^2 = r ^ 2\), the equation of the tangent line is \[(x_0 - a)(x - a) + (y_0 - b)(y - b) = r^2\]

    3. The equation of the tangent line across the circle \(x^2 + y^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0\) is \[x_0 x+y_0 y+\frac{D(x_0+x)}{2}+\frac{E(y_0+y)}{2}+F=0\]

    Note that the tangent point chord equation thatappears below has the same form as this equation, but the meaning of\((x_0,y_0)\) is different.

    Here \((x_0,y_0)\) refers to thecoordinates of a tangent point on the circle, while the latter refers tothe coordinates of a point outside the circle.

5.equation of the tangent chord of a circle and its solution

  1. Tangent chord Definition: Two tangents to acircle are drawn through a point outside the circle,and the line segment through the two tangent points is called thetangent chord of the circle.

  2. The equation of the tangent point chord isfound.

    Directly finding the coordinates of the tangent point is extremelyarithmetic, and considering ** set instead of **.

    That is, set the coordinates of the tangent point, and then use thedefinition of the equation of the line to find the equation of the linewhere the two tangent points are located.

  3. Tangent Point ChordEquation: (You can use it directly for the big question,see ConicCurve - Tangent Point Chord Equation for the full version)

    The line \(AB\) is the chord of thetangent point of the circle \(C\) if\(P(x_0,y_0)\) is drawn to two tangents\(PA,PB\) of the circle \(C\) from a point outsidethe circle.

    1. The equation of the tangent point chord across the unit circle\(x^2 + y^2 = r^2\) is \[x_0x+y_0y = r^2\]

    2. Over the circle \((x - a)^2 + (y - b) ^2 = r ^ 2\), the equation of the chord of the tangent point is\[(x_0 - a)(x - a) + (y_0 - b)(y - b) = r^2\]
